Award.AwardTitle: TRIAD: Reforming Graduate Education by Integrating Teaching, Research, and Industry Applications to Deepen Scientific Understanding

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Title of Project: TRIAD: Reforming Graduate Education by Integrating Teaching, Research, and Industry Applications to Deepen Scientific Understanding
Institutions: Middle Tennessee State University (MTSU); Tennessee State University (TSU)

Co-PIs: Anthony Farone, Ph.D., Mary Farone, Ph.D., E. Lewis Myles, Ph.D., Kim Sadler, Ed.D.

The TRIAD program will make a three-fold connection between graduate fellows (GF), partner teachers (PT) and their high school biology students, and biotechnology/biomedical industry partners (IP) in middle Tennessee. The theme is ?Applications of Cellular and Molecular Biology Research.? TRIAD will allow GFs to (1) improve communication skills through teaching and presentations while sharing their research with PTs, students, other GFs, and IPs; (2) connect their research to applied technologies/products through a classroom biology unit; and (3) interact with industry scientists. Each summer, GF-PT pairs will spend time in the research laboratory of the GF and in the IP?s facility. Following this experience, the GF-PT pair will develop a teaching unit on a research area of interest to the GF-IP. GFs will also mentor high school biology students in research projects. Fellows will help students develop hypotheses, conduct experiments, analyze data, draw conclusions, and submit a presentation to the Tennessee Junior Academy of Science. Intellectual merit of TRIAD includes research to determine if industry interactions and research mentoring experiences create better prepared graduate student scientists, and if engaging PTs and their students in inquiry-based research with GFs will increase standardized test scores in biology and/or encourage more students to pursue STEM careers.

The TRIAD program three-fold interactions will have broad impacts through industry connections and a K-12 experience with STEM graduate education; engaging high school biology students from high-need schools in inquiry-based research; and with industry partnerships extending long-term, sustainable programs impacting the science education continuum (K-20+).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals for TRIAD GK-12 were based on a three-pronged approach of graduate fellows (GFs), partner teachers (PTs) and industry partners (IPs) working together to improve graduate biology education. Partnerships with IPs provided professional experiences and networking opportunities for GFs. We also received an international supplement from NSF to work with scientists, teachers, and IPs in Chile. Through efforts of the PIs, Middle Tennessee State University (MTSU) is sustaining a supplemental GK-12 with a local magnet high school as well as our partnership with Estación Costera de Investigaciones Marinas de la Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile, Las Cruces. Over the six years of TRIAD, we supported 35 GFs and 24 PTs working in Rutherford County and the Metro Nashville, TN public high schools. Our data (classes taught by GFs, GF/PT journals, schedules, and school demographics) for the TRIAD have been archived through a data collection website administered by Vince Hardy, Texas A&M (http://gk12data.org/NSF).

We have prepared educational materials for science teachers that include DVDs disseminated at state, national, and international teacher conferences, and biotechnology videos posted to YouTube (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-5GzJ1AH5e4) and our website (http://www.triadgk12.org/index.html).

Although our theme for TRIAD was cell biology, the cells GFs brought into the classroom ranged from classic models of yeast, plants, and cancer cells to lizards, butterflies, sharks, goats, and guinea fowl. GFs worked in inclusion classrooms to AP classes in six Nashville schools (including one science magnet) and six Rutherford County schools (including one magnet).

GF research was integrated into classroom curricula through a research presentation at the beginning of the school year, and GFs mentoring research projects with student groups throughout the school year, leading to multi-school science symposiums or, as one of the outcomes in our proposal, students submitting research papers to the Tennessee Junior Academy of Science for selection at the annual meeting. In the final years of TRIAD, more than 25% of papers chosen for presentation throughout the state were mentored by our GFs. GFs also produced DVDs for the classroom in which they demonstrated their research techniques/equipment to which students did not have access in their school laboratories. These technique DVDs were disseminated to teachers at local, regional, national, and international meetings.

As part of professional development, GFs and PTs received training from BioTN’s human resource experts, and all of our GFs and PTs received the basic training Presentation Bootcamp workshops developed by Dr. Rick Tankersley of the Florida Institute of Technology.  Several GFs participated in Advanced Training Bootcamp.

Our team of GFs, PTs, and PIs has 77 products listed. TRIAD supported GF travel to two meetings/year, ideally one GK-12 national meeting and one meeting in their scientific discipline. We have logged many miles, conducting 24 national/international presentations, especially for presentations in Chile.  The team constantly emphasized GF development of time management skills to graduate in a timely manner, and 22 of the GFs have graduated with five of the final GFs finishing 2016-2017. GFs have 30 peer-reviewed publications, and one book chapter during or shortly after their tenure in TRIAD.

TRIAD was designed to partner with local life science industries, and we were fortunate to work with Dr. Leslie Wisener-Lynch and Laurene McLemore from the non-profit, BioTN, which provided more than 15 local industry/government internships for the GF/PT pairs.
